childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1952-1964

The smell of Bakelite and metal. The satisfying click of Lincoln Logs locking into place. The weight of a cap gun in your hand, the sulfur snap of each roll. Your childhood had a solidity that children today will never know—toys were made of wood and tin, built to survive being thrown, and they did.

At three, you were probably parked in front of the new television set watching Howdy Doody, mesmerized by that freckled puppet and the Peanut Gallery. By five, you'd graduated to Captain Kangaroo with his gentle voice and Grandfather Clock, to The Mickey Mouse Club with Annette Funicello and those ears everyone wanted. You had strong opinions about whether Spin or Marty was cooler on the Mickey Mouse Club serials. (It was Spin. Obviously.)

Your toys were a statement of the era. Davy Crockett coonskin caps after the Disney miniseries made everyone frontier-crazy. Slinky walking down the stairs. Mr. Potato Head—the original, where you stuck plastic parts into an actual potato because the kit didn't include a plastic body yet. Silly Putty that could copy Sunday comics. Hula Hoops when you were six, and everyone on your block had one spinning.

Saturdays meant one thing: the movie matinee. Walking to the local theater with a quarter—enough for admission, popcorn, and a Coke. The Lone Ranger serials. Roy Rogers and Trigger. Hours of cartoons before the main feature. The distinct smell of that theater—buttered popcorn, worn velvet seats, the musty cool of air conditioning that felt like the future.

You ate Campbell's soup and Swanson TV dinners in their aluminum trays. You drank Ovaltine because Captain Midnight told you to. You begged for Frosted Flakes after Tony the Tiger appeared on your screen. You had a Howdy Doody lunch box and genuinely believed that mattered. You collected baseball cards and flipped them against the schoolyard wall for keeps.

At three, polio was the terror nobody talked about directly but everyone feared. You probably knew a kid who wore leg braces, or knew families who knew families. Dr. Salk's vaccine arrived when you were three, and suddenly the swimming pools reopened. The collective exhale of relief shaped how your generation thinks about vaccines forever.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Baby Boomers

Baby Boomer. The term was coined to describe the demographic explosion when 76 million Americans arrived between 1946 and 1964—soldiers came home, the economy boomed, and everyone got busy making families. You were part of a generation so large that schools had to build new wings, colleges expanded enrollment, and the entire culture bent to accommodate your needs simply because there were so many of you.

You were eleven when President Kennedy was assassinated. November 22, 1963. Sixth grade. You probably watched the news coverage for four straight days—Walter Cronkite removing his glasses, Jackie's pink suit, little John-John's salute. The optimism of the early 1960s curdled that weekend. Before: Camelot, the Space Race, a young president who made the future feel possible. After: a world where presidents could be shot in broad daylight and nothing was certain.

Your generation spans 1946 to 1964—the largest generation in American history until Millennials surpassed you. You bent markets, politics, and culture to your will through sheer numbers. When you needed schools, schools were built. When you needed jobs, the economy expanded. When you reached retirement age, Social Security actuaries started having anxiety attacks.

You were seventeen during the Summer of Love, eighteen when Martin Luther King Jr. and Bobby Kennedy were assassinated two months apart, nineteen during Woodstock. Your late teens were chaos—the Tet Offensive, the Chicago convention riots, the Manson murders, Cambodia. The establishment your parents had built was cracking, and you were the ones with sledgehammers.

You're blamed for a lot now—hoarding wealth, pulling up ladders, voting for policies that benefited you at the expense of your grandchildren. Some of that's fair. Some of it ignores the Boomers who marched at Selma, burned draft cards, and pushed for environmental protections. Your generation is complicated. But then, every generation that thinks it invented moral complexity is.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

Singin' in the Rain came out the year you were born—Gene Kelly splashing through puddles in a way that made everyone believe joy was possible even in a downpour. High Noon gave Gary Cooper to stoic American masculinity. The Greatest Show on Earth won Best Picture, which tells you everything about what Hollywood thought audiences wanted: spectacle, circuses, elephants. These weren't your movies, but they played on television throughout your childhood until you absorbed them like background radiation.

Your actual pop culture education started with television's golden age. At two, you were watching I Love Lucy when 44 million Americans tuned in to see Little Ricky born—more people than watched Eisenhower's inauguration. At four, Dragnet taught you that crime didn't pay and detectives talked in monotone. At six, you discovered The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet and Father Knows Best, shows that presented a version of family life so wholesome it bordered on science fiction.

At four, a truck driver from Memphis named Elvis Presley walked into Sun Records, and nothing was ever the same. By the time you were five, 'Heartbreak Hotel' was everywhere—on the radio, on Ed Sullivan (from the waist up only), in your older siblings' bedrooms where your parents couldn't hear. Your parents thought he was vulgar. You thought he was electric. The generational battle lines were drawn over a pelvis.

High school was the British Invasion. You were twelve when the Beatles landed at JFK, when 73 million people watched them on Ed Sullivan, when your female classmates screamed until they lost their voices. The Rolling Stones were dirtier, Dylan was deeper, but the Beatles were first. You knew every word to 'I Want to Hold Your Hand' before you'd ever held anyone's hand.

At fifteen, Motown was everything—the Supremes, the Temptations, Marvin Gaye, Stevie Wonder. At sixteen, the Beach Boys made you want to surf even if you'd never seen an ocean. At seventeen, Woodstock happened and half a million people gathered in a muddy field while you watched the news coverage and told yourself you would have gone if you could have. (You probably wouldn't have. Almost nobody who claims they were there actually was.)

Movies in your teens shifted from biblical epics to something rawer. At fifteen, Bonnie and Clyde made violence beautiful and outlaws sympathetic. At sixteen, The Graduate taught you that plastics weren't the future and neither was Mrs. Robinson's advice. The Hays Code collapsed when you were sixteen, replaced by the rating system. Suddenly films could show things your parents' movies couldn't even acknowledge existed.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

The whir of a rotary phone dial returning to zero. The clack of typewriter keys striking ribbon against paper. The static hiss before a radio program began. Your childhood was mechanical, analog, physical—every technology had moving parts you could see and sounds you could identify.

At birth, UNIVAC predicted Eisenhower's election victory on CBS, which seemed like witchcraft to your parents. That computer filled an entire room and had less processing power than the greeting card that will play 'Happy Birthday' at your next party. The word 'computer' meant a person who did calculations, usually a woman with a slide rule.

Television was the transformative technology of your childhood, and you were the first generation to grow up with it as standard equipment. Your family probably got their first set when you were three or four—a heavy wooden cabinet with a tiny screen, rabbit ears that needed constant adjusting, and programming that ended at midnight with the national anthem and a test pattern. By seven, over 50 million American homes had one. The whole country started watching the same things at the same time for the first time in human history.

At five, Sputnik crossed the night sky and everything changed. You were too young to fully understand the fear—that the Soviets could put something in orbit meant they could put a bomb anywhere—but you felt your parents' anxiety. The Space Race defined your adolescence. At ten, you watched Alan Shepard's fifteen-minute suborbital flight. At eleven, John Glenn orbited the Earth three times. At seventeen, you watched Neil Armstrong step onto the moon, probably on that same television set that had shown you Howdy Doody, and the world your parents had grown up in became ancient history.

You learned to type on a manual typewriter, probably in high school business class. Mistakes meant Wite-Out or carbon paper nightmares or starting over completely. There was no delete key, no undo, no drafts saved automatically. This shaped how your generation thinks about work—measure twice, cut once, because corrections cost time and money.

The transistor radio arrived when you were six, and suddenly music was portable. The pocket calculator when you were twenty, making slide rules obsolete overnight. The personal computer when you were twenty-nine, the internet when you were forty-three, the smartphone when you were fifty-five. You've adapted to more technological change than any generation in history, from party lines to FaceTime, from letters that took weeks to texts that arrive instantly. And somehow, younger people still act like you can't figure out how to unmute yourself on Zoom.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were two when the Army-McCarthy hearings played out on live television—Senator Joe McCarthy bullying witnesses, Joseph Welch finally asking 'Have you no sense of decency?'—and your parents watched American paranoia peak and then collapse in real time. The Red Scare that had gripped the country began to loosen its hold. You were too young to understand, but the adults around you exhaled.

At three, Rosa Parks refused to give up her bus seat in Montgomery. At eight, four Black college students sat down at a Woolworth's lunch counter in Greensboro and refused to leave. At eleven, Bull Connor turned fire hoses and attack dogs on children in Birmingham. The civil rights movement wasn't something you read about in history class—it was on your television every night while you ate meatloaf and mashed potatoes.

At eleven, Kennedy was assassinated—the defining moment covered in your generational identity. What followed historically: a nation's four-day vigil, then the escalation in Vietnam, then the cascade of assassinations and riots that would define the rest of the decade.

At twelve, the Beatles landed at JFK and you watched teenage girls scream until they fainted. At thirteen, Malcolm X was assassinated. At fifteen, race riots burned through Watts, Newark, Detroit. At sixteen, Martin Luther King Jr. and Bobby Kennedy were both murdered within two months. You were seventeen during the Chicago Democratic Convention riots, where police beat protesters on live television. The establishment your parents had trusted was cracking open.

Vietnam defined your young adulthood. You turned eighteen in 1970, draft eligible, the lottery determining whether you'd go to Southeast Asia or stay home. You either went, got a student deferment, protested, or fled to Canada. There was no neutral position. The war ended when you were twenty-three. The 58,000 American names on that wall in Washington include boys you went to high school with.

At twenty, you watched Nixon resign in disgrace, the first president in American history to do so. At twenty-one, Saigon fell and helicopters evacuated the last Americans from the embassy roof. At twenty-seven, fifty-two Americans were taken hostage in Iran, and you watched the nightly countdown for 444 days. At thirty-seven, the Berlin Wall came down. At forty-nine, you watched the Twin Towers fall. At sixty-eight, a pandemic shut down the world. You've lived through more history than anyone should have to.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

Here's what the deal looked like when you entered the workforce: show up, work hard, stay loyal, retire with a pension and a gold watch. That deal actually existed. Companies hired you expecting you'd stay for decades. They invested in training you because they planned to keep you. The social contract between employer and employee was real, written in benefits and tenure and mutual obligation.

You graduated college around 1974, give or take. The timing wasn't ideal—the OPEC oil embargo had just cratered the economy, gas lines stretched around blocks, and stagflation (high unemployment AND high inflation, which economists had thought was impossible) was grinding everyone down. But here's the thing: even in a bad economy, the fundamentals worked. A college degree cost what you could earn in a summer job. Entry-level positions didn't require five years of experience. A single income could support a family.

If you're a woman, you entered a workforce that was just beginning to crack open. The pill had arrived when you were eight, giving women control over their reproductive futures for the first time. Title IX passed when you were twenty, opening educational doors. You could have a career that didn't involve typing pools or nursing or teaching. The glass ceiling existed—still exists—but at least you were in the building, and you weren't the first generation through the door, just the first with real numbers.

You climbed ladders. That's the metaphor your generation used, and it was accurate—you started at the bottom rung and went up, one promotion at a time, usually at the same company. Job-hopping was considered flaky, disloyal, a red flag on your resume. You accumulated seniority like savings in a bank. The longer you stayed, the more valuable you became, and companies rewarded that with pensions, corner offices, and eventually retirement parties.

The rules changed in your forties and fifties. 'Downsizing' entered the vocabulary. 'Rightsizing.' 'Restructuring.' Pensions converted to 401(k)s, shifting risk from employers to employees. Loyalty became a sucker's bet. You were established enough to mostly survive these changes—you'd already made it to middle management, already secured the pension, already bought the house. But you watched younger colleagues get chewed up by a new economy that treated workers as disposable. The deal you got isn't available anymore. You know that. The question is whether you understand why.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Remember when getting a phone call meant someone in your family picked up the receiver and yelled your name? When asking someone on a date meant calling their house and hoping their father didn't answer? When 'going steady' was announced by wearing his class ring on a chain around your neck, and everyone in school knew the status of every relationship by who was wearing whose jewelry?

You learned courtship through a script your parents had written. First date: movies and milkshakes. Second date: he meets your parents. Going steady: his letterman jacket, his ring, your reputation now linked to his. Pinned, then engaged, then married. There were stages, understood by everyone, and skipping steps had consequences—social ones for boys, life-altering ones for girls.

The sexual revolution rewrote the rulebook while you were learning to date. The pill became available when you were eight, though it would be years before unmarried women could easily get it. By the time you were in college, 'free love' was the rhetoric on campuses, at protests, in the culture. The reality was more complicated—women still bore the consequences of that freedom, and the double standard didn't disappear just because the rules changed.

You probably married younger than seems possible now. The median marriage age in 1975 was 21 for women, 23 for men. Waiting until 25 made you a late bloomer. Waiting until 30 made people wonder what was wrong with you. Marriage was the default, the expected path, the thing you did after college or instead of college. Your grandchildren are delaying marriage into their thirties, and you're not sure if they're wise or afraid.

Communication in your youth was expensive and slow. Long-distance calls cost real money—you watched the clock, you kept it brief, you said what mattered. Love letters were actual letters, written by hand on actual paper, sealed with actual stamps, delivered days later. Breaking up required a conversation, face to face or voice to voice. There was no ghosting when everyone knew everyone, no blocking when you'd see them at church on Sunday.

Divorce rates doubled during your adulthood, from 2.2 per 1,000 people in 1960 to 5.2 by 1980. No-fault divorce arrived when you were eighteen. Women gained financial independence, credit in their own names, the ability to leave. Your generation normalized ending bad marriages instead of enduring them silently. Whether that was liberation or cultural collapse depends on your politics and your own marriage.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

Your parents survived the Great Depression. They remembered standing in bread lines, watching banks fail, losing everything. That memory shaped how they handled money—save obsessively, pay cash, never owe anyone anything, keep emergency funds in places banks couldn't touch. You inherited that caution even if you never lived through the same scarcity. The anxiety passed down even when the conditions didn't.

The numbers tell a story your grandchildren find hard to believe. In 1975, when you were 23, the median home price was $39,300. The median household income was $11,800. A house cost about 3.3 years of income. By comparison, in 2024, the median home is $417,000 and the median income is $80,000—a ratio of 5.2 to 1. You bought your first house with a handshake and a 20% down payment you'd saved from a summer job and your first few years of work. Your grandchildren need six-figure incomes and parental help.

You entered adulthood during genuine economic turbulence—the oil embargo when you were twenty-one, stagflation throughout your twenties, interest rates that hit 18% by 1981. It wasn't easy. But here's what you had: affordable college (you could pay tuition with a part-time job), available jobs (unemployment was high but applications got responses), pensions (real ones, defined benefit, the company's problem not yours), and time. Time is the secret ingredient in compound interest, and you started investing when the Dow was under 1,000.

Your financial journey benefited from time in the market. The basic arithmetic of compound interest rewarded patience—and you had decades to be patient. Houses appreciated while you paid mortgages. Investments grew through bull markets and recovered from bears. Pensions paid out as promised. The system worked the way it was supposed to work, at least for your generation.

Now your financial concerns have shifted from accumulation to preservation. Healthcare costs that can vaporize savings in months. Long-term care expenses that dwarf most retirement accounts. The question of how long your money has to last when longevity keeps extending. Different anxieties than building wealth, but anxieties nonetheless.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your generation's greatest blind spot is the assumption that your experience was universal rather than historically specific. The conditions you navigated—the job markets, housing costs, educational expenses—felt like the natural order of things. Recognizing them as a particular moment requires stepping outside your own story, which is difficult for anyone.

The terrain looked different when you crossed it. You made reasonable decisions based on the landscape available. The challenge is recognizing that the same decisions made today lead to different destinations—not because people are making them wrong, but because the map has changed. What felt like wisdom can become outdated advice faster than anyone expects.

Your generation has a complicated relationship with race that you don't always examine closely. You lived through the civil rights movement. Many of you marched, protested, believed in integration. And then you moved to suburbs, opposed busing, voted for policies that perpetuated segregation through property values and school districts rather than explicit laws. The distance between your stated values and your actual neighborhoods tells a story you'd rather not read.

You're skeptical of institutions while running most of them. Congress, corporate boards, newsrooms, universities, the Supreme Court—Boomers have dominated American leadership for decades and still do. You complain about 'the establishment' as if the establishment were someone else. The call is coming from inside the house. You are the people you've been warning your children about.

Climate change is the blind spot that will define your legacy. You knew—the science has been clear since the 1980s, since you were in your thirties and had power and time. Your generation chose not to act, chose short-term comfort over long-term survival, chose to leave the bill for your grandchildren. You'll be gone before the worst of it hits. The planet you're leaving behind is measurably worse than the one you inherited, and no amount of recycling or hybrid cars will change that calculus. This is what your grandchildren will remember.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (1972-1982): You entered adulthood as America's postwar optimism curdled into malaise. Vietnam ended when you were twenty-three. Nixon resigned when you were twenty-two. The oil embargo tanked the economy when you were twenty-one. Disco happened. You got your first real job during stagflation, probably got married (average age: 23 for men, 21 for women), probably had kids by the end of the decade. The revolutionary energy of your teenage years channeled into mortgages and car payments. This was your decade of foundations—building the infrastructure of a life while the country struggled to remember who it was.

Your 30s (1982-1992): Reagan's America. Morning in America. The economy recovered, and you recovered with it. You were hitting your stride professionally—middle management, maybe upper management, corner offices and expense accounts. The Yuppie was the cultural archetype, and if you lived in a city, you probably owned a BMW or a Volvo and opinions about wine. Your kids were in elementary school, then middle school. You bought a bigger house in a better school district. The Cold War ended right as you hit forty—the Berlin Wall fell when you were thirty-seven, the Soviet Union collapsed when you were thirty-nine. The future looked like pure possibility. This was your decade of accumulation.

Your 40s (1992-2002): Clinton, the tech boom, irrational exuberance. You were in your peak earning years, and the economy was a rocket ship. Your 401(k) doubled, then doubled again. Your house appreciated so fast it felt like free money. Your kids were teenagers, which brought its own challenges—AOL, MySpace, music you didn't understand. You started thinking seriously about retirement, maybe bought a vacation property, definitely upgraded the kitchen. Then, at forty-nine, you watched the Twin Towers fall, and the optimism evaporated again. The world got darker. This was your decade of peak prosperity.

Your 50s (2002-2012): The War on Terror. Afghanistan, then Iraq, then the forever wars that replaced the Cold War as background anxiety. The housing bubble inflated and then exploded when you were fifty-six. You watched your 401(k) crater—you were close enough to retirement that this wasn't abstract. Your kids were adults now, struggling in ways that confused you, burdened by student loans you didn't have, locked out of housing markets you entered easily. You started counting down to retirement while wondering if you could still afford it. This was your decade of uncertainty.

Your 60s (2012-2022): You retired, or you didn't, or you tried and then went back because you were bored or broke or both. Your friends started dying—not in tragic accidents, but in the ordinary ways that bodies fail. Your parents died if they hadn't already. You became the oldest generation in your family, a strange promotion you didn't ask for. The world changed in ways that felt alien—smartphones everywhere, gender more complicated than you were taught, politics unrecognizable, young people who didn't remember the world before the internet. At sixty-eight, a pandemic shut everything down. You spent a year inside, vulnerable, waiting for vaccines that came remarkably fast but still too slow. This was your decade of letting go.

Your 70s and beyond (2022+): You're here now. You've witnessed more history than most humans in any era—from Eisenhower to Biden, from no television to virtual reality, from segregation to a Black president and back to whatever this is. Your body doesn't work like it used to, but medicine keeps extending what's possible. Your friends are dying, faster now. You're making peace with mortality or raging against it, depending on the day. You're telling stories about the world before smartphones to grandchildren who look at you like you're describing science fiction. You're still here, still adapting, still watching a world that keeps changing without asking permission. Not bad for a kid who grew up sticking plastic features into actual potatoes and calling it a toy.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

3.9 million Americans were born the same year as you, part of the 76 million Baby Boomers who arrived between 1946 and 1964. You were the largest generation in American history until Millennials surpassed you—and you've shaped every institution you've touched through sheer demographic weight.

Compared to the Silent Generation (born 1928-1945): They were shaped by scarcity—the Depression, rationing, war. You were shaped by abundance—postwar prosperity, suburban expansion, consumer culture. They conformed; you questioned. They trusted institutions that had won a world war; you watched those institutions lie about Vietnam and break into Watergate. They called you spoiled. You called them square. You were both right.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): You got pensions and they got 401(k)s. You got affordable college and they got the beginnings of the student loan crisis. You got the good jobs before globalization and automation hollowed out the middle class. They came of age as the economy shifted from manufacturing to services, from stability to precarity. They're called the forgotten generation, sandwiched between your massive cohort and the Millennials. They're the ones who'll clean up after you.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996): The wealth gap tells the story. When Boomers were in their forties, your generation controlled 21% of national wealth. Millennials at the same age control 7%. You bought houses for two to three years' salary; they're looking at six to eight times theirs, if they can look at all. You had pensions that guaranteed retirement income; they have student debt and 401(k)s that depend on market timing. The math changed. They're not lazy; they're operating in a different economy.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): You might as well be from different planets. They've never known a world without the internet, without smartphones, without school shooting drills. Climate anxiety is their baseline emotional state. They're more diverse, more tolerant, more skeptical of institutions—including the American Dream itself. They look at your generation and see the people who knew about climate change for forty years and chose not to act, who accumulated wealth and pulled up ladders, who are still running institutions into the ground. They're not impressed by your Woodstock stories.

Your life expectancy at birth was 68 years for men, 74 for women. You've beaten the odds—modern medicine, better nutrition, declining smoking rates, and luck have given your generation more healthy years than any before. You're redefining what 70 and 80 look like, staying active and engaged and online and opinionated. The question isn't whether you'll live long. It's what kind of world you'll leave behind, and whether your grandchildren will forgive you for it.

year_events: Mr. Potato Head becomes first toy advertised on TV
